abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Technical Assistance for
            Economic Reform Project for India were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: A
            flexible, open technical assistance (TA) facility of this
            nature with no upfront links with other Bank operations
            should not be considered at all. A multi-sector TA project
            of this kind, with multiple implementing agencies should
            have a well designed information flow mechanism, with
            special attention to financial flows and reporting. At least
            50 percent to 60 percent of the project funds for a project
            of this nature should be committed (in terms of contracts
            awarded) before the project goes to the Board. A monitoring
            and evaluation (M&E) framework to assess impact of the
            overall project as well as the sub-projects should be a part
            of project design. For a project of this nature such a
            facility is likely to generate more interest if it is a
            grant rather than a loan. Terms and conditions of accessing
            funds should be clearly communicated to all entities. A
            small part of the credit proceeds should be earmarked to
            allow for learning across states and implementing agencies.
            The capacity of the project monitoring unit  (PMU) to
            execute such complex multi-sector TA should be assessed and
            addressed upfront.
